Photo Resolution & Size

How to determine if a photo has sufficient resolution to print well


Screen vs. Printing

How an image looks on screen and how it will look printed are not the same. How large an image appears on screen and how large it will appear printed are not the same. [This section will help you select images that will look good when printed.]



Definitions

Pixel:  The tiny squares that a digital image is made up of Pixel dimensions of an image: The total pixel dimensions of an image will tell you how many total pixels the image is made up of (e.g. 3456 x 2304).


        Image at 100% size                     Close-up of center of flower

                                                         (blocks are individual pixels)


 

From Photoshop's IMAGE SIZE dialogue box


Digital Image Size: The size in inches of your digital image. Photoshop's dialogue box calls it Document Size. (IMPORTANT: This does not necessarily mean your image will print out and look good at this size)


 

From Photoshop's IMAGE SIZE dialogue box


PPI of digital image:  PPI means Pixels Per Inch. Your computer screen displays images at 72PPI. For an image to look good when printed it needs to be at least 225PPI (300PPI is best and should be your target)


 

From Photoshop's IMAGE SIZE dialogue box



Screen Resolution vs. printing resolution

Images on your computer monitor are displayed at 72 pixels/inch. But when you print an image you will need more pixels per inch if you want the image to look good (crisp and not "pixelated"). Generally speaking images should have a resolution of at least 225 pixels per inch, and be the actual size they will be printed, for them to look good. 300 pixels per inch is preferred. How will you know the resolution and size of the image? You need to use Photoshop.



Open your image in Photoshop

To understand how your image will look when printed you have to open it in Photoshop. In the top menu bar there will be an option called IMAGE. Under that dropdown menu is an option called IMAGE SIZE. Open that dialogue. Many images (nearly all that come from a Web site) will show a resolution of 72 pixels/inch. What does this mean? It has to do with how the image is displayed.


 

Photoshop's IMAGE SIZE dialogue box



Do the math

A digital image has a fixed number of pixels. You can find that number in the pixel dimensions part of the IMAGE SIZE dialogue. This image described in the box at the right is 500 x 333 pixels. The document size part of the box indicates the image is 6.9 inches wide. This is only true at 72 pixels/inch. Let's look at the math:


       500px ÷ 72px/in = 6.944 inches


If you want to print your image it needs to be at least 225 pixels/in (preferably 300px/in). Photoshop will do this math for you type in your desired resolution (NOTE: be sure the resample image checkbox at the bottom of the dialogue is unchecked). If you type in 225 you will see that the new math gives us:


       500px ÷ 225px/in = 2.222 inches


This means that the largest you can expect to print this image and have it look good is about 2 inches wide.



Testing an image

What if you already have an image but you're still not sure how big it will be (can be) when printed. You can test it using Photoshop. You first have to know how big you want the image to be when you print it. Let's say you are making a flyer and you need the image to be 3" x 4". Make a new Photoshop document (FILE/NEW). In the document settings enter 3" wide, 4" high and 300 pixels/inch.


Copy and paste your image into this new document. It will show at the size it will print correctly.



What if your image is not large enough?

Let's say that you have followed the procedure above to set your resolution to 225 pixels/in. You unchecked the resample image box and you typed 225 into the resolution box. But your image is only 4" wide. You need it to be 6" wide. In order to make the image larger you actually have to add pixels to the image. Photoshop will do this. And it will do a pretty good job if you don't increase the size too much.



Letting Photoshop resample an image

To make your 4" image 6" wide you need to add 450 pixels to the width (225 pixels/in x 2" = 450 new pixels). Check the resample image box at the bottom of the dialogue box. You will notice that the pixel dimensions at the top of the box will become editable fields again. When you type 6" into the width box you will see that the width in pixels will increase to 1350 pixels from it's original size.



At the bottom of the box is an dropdown menu.

Choose Bicubuic Smoother (best for enlargement), because it does a good job of enlarging images. When you hit OK at the top of the box Photoshop will add pixels to the image and do its best to make it look natural.



How much can you enlarge?

That depends on your tolerance for quality. We want your images to look good so they represent your events well. We would recommend not increasing an image more than 50%. That is what we used for the example above. From 4" to 6" is a 50% increase in size.



What happens if you increase the image too much?

When you increase the image too much Photoshop has to add so many pixels that the image begins to look fuzzy and "pixelated". It will be obvious that the image has been enlarged.
